Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: You know your own degrees; sit down. At first And last, the hearty welcome.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lords
Act3Scene4.text: Thanks to your Majesty.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host. Our hostess keeps her state, but in best time We will require her welcome.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Pronounce it for me, sir, to all our friends, For my heart speaks they are welcome.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: See, they encounter thee with their hearts’ thanks. Both sides are even. Here I’ll sit i’ th’ midst.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Be large in mirth. Anon we’ll drink a measure The table round.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Murderer
Act3Scene4.text: ’Tis Banquo’s then.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: ’Tis better thee without than he within. Is he dispatched?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Murderer
Act3Scene4.text: My lord, his throat is cut.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Thou art the best o’ th’ cutthroats, Yet he’s good that did the like for Fleance. If thou didst it, thou art the nonpareil.
Act3Scene4.translation: You are the best of cutthroats, but whoever did the same to FLeance is just as good. I you killed Fleance, you would be a cutthroat with no equal.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Murderer
Act3Scene4.text: Most royal sir, Fleance is ’scaped.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Then comes my fit again. I had else been perfect but now I am bound in to saucy doubts and fears. —But Banquo’s safe?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Murderer
Act3Scene4.text: Ay, my good lord.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Thanks for that. There the grown serpent lies.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: The worm that’s fled Hath nature that in time will venom breed, No teeth for th’ present.
Act3Scene4.translation: The worm that's escaped will in time become venomous, but for now has no fangs.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Get thee gone. Tomorrow We’ll hear ourselves again.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: My royal lord, You do not give the cheer. The sauce to meat is ceremony; Meeting were bare without it.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Sweet remembrancer!— Now, good digestion wait on appetite And health on both!

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lennox
Act3Scene4.text: May ’t please your Highness sit.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Here had we now our country’s honor roofed, Were the graced person of our Banquo present, Who may I rather challenge for unkindness Than pity for mischance.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Ross
Act3Scene4.text: His absence, sir, Lays blame upon his promise. Please ’t your Highness To grace us with your royal company?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: The table’s full.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lennox
Act3Scene4.text: Here is a place reserved, sir.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Where?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lennox
Act3Scene4.text: Here, my good lord. What is ’t that moves your Highness?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Which of you have done this?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lords
Act3Scene4.text: What, my good lord?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Thou canst not say I did it. Never shake Thy gory locks at me.
Act3Scene4.translation: You can't say I did it. Don't shake your bloody head at me.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Ross
Act3Scene4.text: Gentlemen, rise. His Highness is not well.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Sit, worthy friends. My lord is often thus And hath been from his youth.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: If much you note him You shall offend him and extend his passion. Feed and regard him not.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Are you a man?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on that Which might appall the devil.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: O, proper stuff! This is the very painting of your fear. When all’s done, You look but on a stool.
Act3Scene4.translation: This is just a hallucination brought by fear. When it's all over, you'll see it's just a stool.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Prithee, see there. Behold, look! Lo, how say you? Why, what care I? If thou canst nod, speak too.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: What, quite unmanned in folly?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: If I stand here, I saw him.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Fie, for shame!

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: The time has been That, when the brains were out, the man would die, And there an end. But now they rise again.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: This is more strange Than such a murder is.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: My worthy lord, Your noble friends do lack you.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: I do forget.— Do not muse at me, my most worthy friends. I have a strange infirmity, which is nothing To those that know me.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Come, love and health to all. Then I’ll sit down.—Give me some wine. Fill full.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: I drink to th’ general joy o’ th’ whole table And to our dear friend Banquo, whom we miss. Would he were here! To all, and him we thirst, And all to all.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lords
Act3Scene4.text: Our duties, and the pledge.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Avaunt, and quit my sight!

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Think of this, good peers, But as a thing of custom. ’Tis no other; Only it spoils the pleasure of the time.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Horrible shadow! Unreal mock’ry, hence! Why so, being gone, I am a man again.—Pray you sit still.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: You have displaced the mirth, broke the good meeting With most admired disorder.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Can such things be And overcome us like a summer’s cloud, Without our special wonder?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Ross
Act3Scene4.text: What sights, my lord?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: I pray you, speak not. He grows worse and worse. At once, good night. Go at once.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lennox
Act3Scene4.text: Good night, and better health Attend his Majesty.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: A kind good night to all.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: What is the night?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Almost at odds with morning.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: How say’st thou that Macduff denies his person At our great bidding?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Did you send to him, sir?

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: I hear it by the way; but I will send. I will tomorrow to the Weïrd Sisters. More shall they speak.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Strange things I have in head that will to hand, Which must be acted ere they may be scanned.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: You lack the season of all natures, sleep.

Act3Scene4.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene4.text: Come, we’ll to sleep.
